div1.p: I have the honor to refer to my report 486/236 of last June the 14th.

Returning before yesterday in Washington, at the end of my consular inspection, I learned that the superior civil servant with whom I've had conversations about the Congo was absent and did not return qu'on Septembre. He advised me to go see Mr. Adee, one of the assistant Secretaries of State, to whom Mr. Knox told me recently to entrust the direction of relative matter in the Congo.

I just talked with Mr. Adee. From the first words, this one spontaneously spoke with me of the symapathy and of the great confidence that our King and his government inspires to the United States Government, in particular with their action towards the issues in the Congo.
He made the following declaration, that I also reproduce litterally everything possible,- and a ajouré, in response to my question, that he speek of the name of the Secretary of State:

"We have examined what there is to do concerning the acknowledgement of the annexation of the Congo, and we have found that one formal declaration of acknowledgement isn't generally considered as necessary, nor even generally common.- (I told Mr. Adee that I was of the same opinon never having, in accordance with the views of the Government of the King, demanded the formal accomplishment of this act.)"

"We consider, - the Secretary of State then said- that we have already recognized the de facto annexation of the Congo to the Belgians, -and by the recent extension of our minimal tarif to this colony, and by the form of
Mr. Davignon Brussels Minister of Foreign Affaires.
contact form our Consuls in Congo with your authorities."

"When the United States annexed Alaska, and then Hawaï they did not judge that they know to wait for Power one recognition in any special form." I repeat, we have recognized the de facto annexation of the Congo"

"I add that your King and your Government, thanks to their evident wishes of establishing what we call non of the "reforms" (a term which was used excessively) but the "necessary modification", possessing good wishes, sympathy and the entire confidence for the United States Government. "The sentiments that I've expressed are shared by all the members in the Department of State."
"You are completely authorised to repeat the declaration that I just made to the King of Belgium and to his Government."

In thanking Mr. Adee, I told him in confidence that we were rested up to here with the last exchanges of devoted writing that was linked between our two Governments,- documents taht were not marked with the same character as the present declaration; and for this reason, this one was very well welcomed.

He responded to me that at the time of the Secretary of State's return, he was able to envisage with him the question of knowing if one ce written could add someting within reach of what he had just told me.
Yours sincerely, Mr. Ministre, etc... (s.) of Buisseret
